source: Public Research Papers – Brigham Young University papers
papers: Learning From Lessons Learned: Preliminary Findings From a Study of Learning From Failure

level_1: This paper discusses how teams can learn from real-world system failures through post-mortems and collaborative reflection.
The research investigates why organizations struggle to apply incident insights into long-term improvements.
level_2: It shows how incidents trigger learning not just from root causes but from a wide range of failure contexts.
Interviews and incident reports reveal recurring gaps in organizational memory and follow-up actions.
level_3: The study uses open-ended interviews and public post-mortems to understand multi-level learning failures.
It highlights how organizational inertia and shifting priorities reduce long-term retention of lessons.
level_4: Advanced themes include designing interventions and tools for sustainable learning from incidents.
Future models aim to address socio-technical complexity in failure-driven evolution of systems.

level_1: Teams forgetting critical config lessons after minor outages.
level_2: Adding alerting tools post-incident to detect similar issues faster.
level_3: Identifying cascading failures and logging gaps from large-scale outages.
level_4: Adapting incident learnings to support cross-team knowledge transfer in complex systems.

level_1: SRE and DevOps teams conduct root cause post-mortems.
level_2: Engineering orgs improve monitoring and rollback workflows after failures.
level_3: Incident lessons drive roadmap changes in reliability engineering.
level_4: Tooling and frameworks for continuous learning from system-wide failure data.

level_1: Ask: Did this incident reveal a known issue we ignored?
level_2: Ask: Did responders have the tools and data to act fast?
level_3: Ask: Are there recurring failure themes across teams?
level_4: Ask: How do lessons persist as people and priorities change?

level_1: Not applying previous lessons to current projects.
level_2: No actions assigned to key lessons from a post-mortem.
level_3: Lessons isolated to specific teams with no broader sharing.
level_4: Loss of organizational memory due to team turnover or shift in strategy.

level_2: Why might monitoring systems be a focus after an incident?
level_3: Explain why lessons may not spread beyond the original team.

level_1: Write a brief post-mortem for a mock deployment error.
level_2: Simulate a detection-and-response timeline for a database outage.

level_1: Don’t skip documenting smaller outages — they often reveal useful insights.
level_2: Always define action items for each lesson in a post-mortem.
level_3: Avoid assuming lessons will naturally spread—build knowledge transfer processes.
level_4: Don’t expect old lessons to stay relevant without revisiting them over time.
